summary: influenza is an acute viral infection of the respiratory tract caused by influenza type A, B, and C viruses of the Orthomyxoviridae family. the periodic emergence of novel influenza strains can result in widespread pandemics capable of extensive morbidity and mortality. the vast majority of reported cases have been mild and self-limiting [4]–[6]; typical symptoms have included fever, sore throat, malaise, and headache [7] IL-6 is the chief mediator of the acute phase response and fever [14]. IL-6 has been implicated in the cytokine storm following avian influenza A H5N1 and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) infection [16]–[18]. IL-6 levels have been associated with symptom duration and severity in cases of seasonal influenza infection. a total of 45 hospitalized patients with laboratory-confirmed H1N1pdm infection were included in our analysis. Lung tissue collected at day 3 pi. n = 3 for IL-6/ mice and n = 3 for IL-6 wild-type mice. vertical error bars indicate +1 standard deviation. inflammatory mediator IL-6 has been implicated in both avian influenza A and SARS-induced cytokine storms [16]–[18], [33], and from our data in humans we hypothesized that IL-6 would have a similar damaging role during severe H1N1pdm infection. we investigated IL-6 levels in three mouse strains infected with H1N1pdm. Previously, Otte et al. reported that BALB/cJ mice were less susceptible than C57BL/6J mice to H1N1pdm infection. however, we found that C57BL/6J, BALB/cJ, and B6129SF2/J mice were similarly susceptible to H1N1pdm infection. our findings implicated IL-6 in the host response to H1N1pdm in mice. IL-6-mediated inflammatory response genes were prominently upregulated. IL-6 protein levels were elevated in mice infected with 104 EID50. IL-6/ mice were not protected during H1N1pdm infection. IL-1 and TNF- signalling are negatively regulated by IL-6. this could explain why IL-6/ mice were not protected. IL-6 deficiency did not impact disease outcome in C57BL/6J mice. but the consistent association of IL-6 with severe disease suggests host response elements that contribute to disease may be regulated by a common upstream event. further investigation is critical to elucidate the role of IL-6 as a disease severity marker in influenza, specifically severe H1N1pdm. IL-6 deficiency in mice had no significant bearing on any of the clinical manifestations studied. study suggests IL-6 may serve as an important biomarker for the identification of patients at risk of severe complications following H1N1pdm infection. qRT-PCR using either the Influenza A (H1N1) MGB Detection Assay from Applied Biosystems (Carlsbad, CA, USA) or the RealTime Ready Influenza A/H1N1 Detection Set from Roche® (Basel, Switzerland) 45 hospitalized patients with laboratory-confirmed H1N1pdm were enrolled in the study. mice were kept on standard animal feed and water ad libitum in clean environmental conditions. animals were housed in HEPA-filtered cage racks adherent to ABSL2+ conditions. all animal procedures were performed in a certified class II biosafety cabinet. mice (n = 3) were euthanized and lung homogenates collected for viral load determination. lungs were homogenized (10% w/v) in DMEM supplement. qRT-PCR was performed using the ABI-Prism 7900HT Sequence Detection Systems. each reaction well contained 0.25 L of 20 ng/uL cDNA, 0.5 L each of forward and reverse primers, for a total reaction volume of 10 uL. time series analysis was performed with Extraction of Differential Gene Expression (EDGE) software. Benjamini-Hochberg correction was employed to assess the occurrence of false positives. both age and sex were identified as confounding variables. the Student’s t-test ( = 0.05) was used to identify statistically significant increases in expression of genes assayed by qRT-PCR. only those patients with confirmed H1N1pdm by qRT-PCR were included in the study. a total of 45 hospitalized patients with laboratory-confirmed H1N1pdm were enrolled. female C57BL/6J, BALB/cJ, B6129SF2/J, and B6.129S2-Il6tm1Kopf/J (IL-6/) mice (8–10 weeks of age) were purchased from Jackson Laboratories (Bar Harbor, MN, USA) and used in influenza studies.
